text: when I was the director of the shakes
theater in statford Connecticut I was
staying at a a a famous French teacher
named Michelle sanon home and I picked
up a copy of Shakespeare and I and I
read Henry 5 now I this was right during
the Vietnamese War and I was opposed to
the war as almost everybody my age was
at the time and uh and I thought I don't
want to do Henry 5 my knowledge of Henry
5 was from Lawrence Olivier's film which
was a very famous film it was clearly a
nationalistic
jingoistic epic and I got to
the first scene of the play after the
chorus does of mus of fire and there's
the bishop of elely and the Archbishop
of canary talking about how Henry wants
to tax them
inordinately and they're going to lose
their lands and some of their wealth so
what can they do to dissuade him or
really to turn his attention away from
this I thought oh my Lord this is this
is already extraordinarily powerful
thing where the church is lying to the
king to set him to go to war not for
anything other than their own
reasons that for somebody in their late
was perfect so I said I'm going to do
this play and then I found out other
things that Henry does he kills the
French prisoners against the rules of
engagement or when he kills his best
friend
bardol so I I did this very Brey and
cynical production very modern and we
lit candles at the end you know and
March to 42nd Street for a candlelight
vigil but I had difficulty I could do
all of that all the tough stuff about
hawks and doves and killing prisoners
but when it came to all the great
speeches like say chrisp and chrispian
and and once more into the breach dear
friends I couldn't I had to turn them
around in some way and say they were
propaganda I had to take all of that
greatness away in order to make my
theory that this was a anti-war
anti-government play when I came back to
do it again and I had realized over the
years that the genius of Shakespeare is
not that it's anti-war or pro-war
anti-government or PR government but
that the issue of leading a country is
the comp ated one perhaps you do things
in order to for the country that are
somewhat Shady perhaps you do things
that are against you because you know
it's better for the whole you can be
heroic and you can be shallow you can be
idealistic and yet still have some
cynicism you can be all of these things
in a rounded character so I I did almost
the same physical production four years
later except my emphasis was on the
contradictions in hand hry you know I I
you can you can do a lot of what you
want with Shakespeare but I like to
suggest the directors that Shakespeare's
thought is wider and richer than our own
because Shakespeare doesn't have a moral
point of view he is imminently
reinterpret by generation after
generation or Century after century and
it's right to do so the plays are there
to be looked at aresh each
time
